title: Environmental and genetic drivers of population differences in SARS-CoV-2 immune responses

finding: The SNP rs181391313 was found in a putative microglia-specific intronic enhancer of the STAB1 gene, disrupting a KLF4 binding site, which supports a novel gene-disease association within the context of PD.
title: Single-cell epigenomic identification of inherited risk loci in Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s disease

finding: SNP rs6781790 disrupted a predicted CTCFL binding site at the promoter of the WDR6 gene and showed allelic imbalance across multiple ATAC-seq samples, indicating its functional relevance.
title: Single-cell epigenomic identification of inherited risk loci in Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s disease

finding: The SNP rs9877502 was found to be associated with volumes of specific hippocampal subfields, particularly increasing CA1-3 volumes and decreasing other subfield volumes. This SNP was previously linked to Alzheimer's disease risk and cognitive decline, hence providing insights into its role in brain structure and neurogenesis.
title: A fast non-parametric test of association for multiple traits

finding: This SNP was also located within HARs and significantly associated with beat synchronization. It was shown to regulate GBE1 expression and linked to neuromuscular disease, emphasizing the genetic correlations between muscle function, reaction time, and rhythmic coordination.
title: Genome-wide association study of musical beat synchronization demonstrates high polygenicity

finding: The SNP rs9985399 was associated with brain processing speed in the Lothian birth cohort. It was highlighted as being located within the <italic>MYRIP</italic> gene, which has implications for cognitive function affected in psychiatric illnesses, including schizophrenia and depression.
title: SNP and Haplotype Regional Heritability Mapping (SNHap-RHM): joint mapping of common and rare variation affecting complex traits

finding: The SNP rs6599077 was identified to be associated with sleep duration, which is notably linked to increased risk of major depressive disorder. Like rs9985399, it is situated within the <italic>MYRIP</italic> gene region, emphasizing the gene's role in psychiatric phenotypes.
title: SNP and Haplotype Regional Heritability Mapping (SNHap-RHM): joint mapping of common and rare variation affecting complex traits

finding: At the FOXL2 locus, rs147843771 was established as a target gene based on literature evidence. This SNP's significance was highlighted as part of a broader analysis of gestational duration in women.
title: Transcriptome and regulatory maps of decidua-derived stromal cells inform gene discovery in preterm birth

finding: At the 3q21 locus, rs144609957 was associated with gestational duration (GWAS p = 4 x 10^-13) and was involved in chromatin interactions with the promoter of GATA2. This implicates GATA2 as a candidate causal gene for gestational duration and preterm birth.
title: Transcriptome and regulatory maps of decidua-derived stromal cells inform gene discovery in preterm birth

finding: The risk variant rs11707416 was discovered in the most recent Parkinson's disease GWAS with a P-value of 1.13E-10 and an odds ratio (OR) of 0.94. Despite showing a clear GWAS signal, the closest gene <italic>MED12L</italic> was not prioritized as the primary candidate. Instead, <italic>P2RY12</italic> emerged as the top candidate based on a conclusion score of 7, indicating a high association with the risk locus. This finding highlighted the complexity of the locus, where multiple genes were encoded within an intron of <italic>MED12L</italic>.
title: The Parkinson’s Disease GWAS Locus Browser

finding: The SNP rs2131107 was identified as a natural variant in the DAG1 gene, specifically presenting the amino acid substitution S14W. This finding was significant as it related to the mapping of O-Man glycoproteins and the targeted analysis of glycosylation pathways, providing insights into the functional implications of this genetic variation in terms of the protein's biological roles during cell interactions.
title: Global view of domain-specific O-linked mannose glycosylation in glycoengineered cells

finding: The SNP rs13071666 was associated with the study conducted by Parker et al. in 2021, which highlighted the regulatory roles of O-GlcNAcylation in gene transcription, particularly in cancer contexts. In this study, the connection of O-GlcNAc transferase activity and cancer stem-like cell induction was elucidated, reinforcing the importance of high glucose levels in promoting tumorigenic mechanisms in triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC). The findings articulated how aberrant sugar-transfer processes could contribute to cancer pathways, thus emphasizing the relevance of this SNP in understanding the genetic implications of obesity-related cancer risk.
title: Hyperglycemic O-GlcNAc transferase activity drives cancer stem cell induction in TNBC

finding: The study indicated that the single nucleotide polymorphism at rs6763931 in the ZBTB38 gene was highly correlated with ZBTB38 expression in the blood. Moreover, genome-wide association studies demonstrated that ZBTB38 was strongly associated with height, providing a connection between genetic variation at this locus and a specific phenotype, thus affirming its significance in genetic studies.
title: Zbtb38 inhibits apoptosis by transcriptionally regulating XIAP expression

finding: The low frequency intergenic variant rs112097551, recognized at the GATA2-RPN1 locus, was associated with mean corpuscular volume (MCV), mean corpuscular hemoglobin (MCH), and red blood cell count. Its frequency was approximately 5 times higher in African populations versus non-African samples, and it showed strong conservation with a CADD Phred score of 20.4, indicating it is among the top 1% of deleterious variants. Despite the expectation of limited eQTL evidence, the variant was shown to link to RUVBL1 and noncoding transcripts based on PCHi-C data, and it was selected for in vitro follow-up.
title: From GWAS Variant to Function: a Study of ~148,000 Variants for Blood Cell Traits

finding: The SNP rs121912606 was linked to the pathogenic variant p.R79Q in the ARL13B gene (Protein ID = NP_001167621.1). It had a low allele frequency of 3.98e-6 and was associated with Joubert syndrome. This finding highlighted its significance in the context of genetic variations related to this particular disease.
title: MSABrowser: dynamic and fast visualization of sequence alignments, variations, and annotations

finding: The SNP rs1482852 was associated with various parameters of fetal growth and metabolic programming. It was related to adiposity in newborns, maternal adiponectin levels, cord blood leptin, and insulin release after an oral glucose challenge, signifying its potential role in influencing growth regulation and metabolic activity in the developing fetus.
title: Placental DNA methylation signatures of maternal smoking during pregnancy and potential impacts on fetal growth

finding: The SNP rs900400, identified in conjunction with rs1482852, was implicated in fetal growth and metabolic responses. The C-allele of this SNP was associated with elevated insulin release during an oral glucose challenge, underlying its involvement in metabolic programming linked to maternal smoking during pregnancy.
title: Placental DNA methylation signatures of maternal smoking during pregnancy and potential impacts on fetal growth

finding: The SNP rs13322435, associated with rs1482852 and rs900400, was also reported in genetic studies to be involved in fetal growth parameters. This association reinforced the significance of this locus on chromosome 3 in metabolic and growth regulation, especially in the context of maternal smoking.
title: Placental DNA methylation signatures of maternal smoking during pregnancy and potential impacts on fetal growth

finding: The SNP rs6801957 demonstrated a notable association with ECG morphology, achieving P=3×10^-133, and was located in the SCN10A gene.
title: The genetic makeup of the electrocardiogram

finding: The variant rs4685090 was linked with DCM association with P=4.2×10^-6, situated near the LSM3 gene, though its role in cardiac biology remains unclear.
title: The genetic makeup of the electrocardiogram

finding: SNP rs1706003 was associated with diastolic blood pressure (DBP) with a P-value of 1.1×10^-7. The integration of heart-derived eQTL data provided stronger evidence for its association (MR P=7.8×10^-7). Although TMEM44 was the nearest gene, the results indicated that ATP13A3, located further downstream, was likely responsible for the observed blood pressure effect.
title: A transcriptome-wide Mendelian randomization study to uncover tissue-dependent regulatory mechanisms across the human phenome

finding: The SNP rs1389713 was found on BTA12, approximately 182 kb upstream of the DACH1 gene, which is associated with key traits related to growth and feed efficiency in cattle. This finding contributed significantly to the identification of selection pressures in breeds selected for improved growth and efficiency traits.
title: Powerful detection of polygenic selection and environmental adaptation in US beef cattle populations

finding: The SNP rs73178598 was found to interact with the promoter of SATB1, an antisense RNA gene previously unlinked to psoriasis. This interaction indicated its potential importance in regulating Tregs and autoimmunity, thereby contributing to psoriasis pathology.
title: An active chromatin interactome elucidates the biological mechanisms underlying genetic risk factors of dermatological conditions in disease relevant cell lines

finding: This SNP was identified as a cis-pQTL for the protein ITIH1, which serves as a biomarker for high-altitude adaptation and was associated with hemoglobin measurement.
title: CoffeeProt: An online tool for correlation and functional enrichment of proteome-wide systems genetics

finding: This SNP was identified as a missense variant of ITIH3, associated with erythrocyte counts and contributing to the genetic profile of blood traits.
title: CoffeeProt: An online tool for correlation and functional enrichment of proteome-wide systems genetics

finding: The SNP rs13081866 was found to be associated with the gene FEN1, which was identified as a crucial enzyme in the DNA damage response pathway. The study indicated that targeting FEN1 could enhance the chemo-sensitivity of cancer cells to platinum-based therapies. This connection underscored the importance of DNA repair mechanisms in chemotherapy resistance, particularly in the context of ovarian cancers, supporting the therapeutic potential of FEN1 blockade.
title: Exploring the effect of capsaicin on gene expression and chemotherapy sensitization in gastric cancer cells

finding: The analysis suggested that rs113010081 was a better proxy for the CCR5-Δ32 deletion compared to rs62625034. It showed no significant deviations from HWE and was associated with several phenotypes potentially related to immune function, confirming its relevance in genetic studies related to the CCR5 gene.
title: No statistical evidence for an effect of CCR5-Δ32 on lifespan in the UK Biobank cohort

finding: This SNP was part of a trans-eQTL that affected 34 target genes, with 78% of these showing decreased expression when the archaic allele was present. This highlighted its role in gene expression modulation linked to Neandertal ancestry.
title: Long-range regulatory effects of Neandertal DNA in modern humans

finding: Analyzed together with rs13098911, this SNP also affected 34 genes, demonstrating significant expression decrease associated with the archaic allele, reinforcing its role in regulatory mechanisms tied to Neandertal DNA.
title: Long-range regulatory effects of Neandertal DNA in modern humans

finding: The finding related to rs28732378 was significant in the variant-based GWAS with a p-value of 3.4e-10, and it was noted that it overlaps with top (but non-significant) results from the QGS-based analysis.
title: Quantitative Genetic Scoring, or how to put a number on an arbitrary genetic region

finding: The SNP rs35124509, located in the exonic region of the EPHA3 gene on chromosome 3, was associated with lower connectivity in minor allele carriers (C, MAF = 0.39) compared to non-carriers. However, higher connectivity was observed for a minority of edges.
title: Imaging genetics of language network functional connectivity reveals links with language-related abilities, dyslexia and handedness

finding: The lead SNP rs2279829, situated upstream of the ZIC4 gene on chromosome 3, exhibited increased average connectivity in minor allele carriers (T, MAF = 0.21) as compared to non-carriers.
title: Imaging genetics of language network functional connectivity reveals links with language-related abilities, dyslexia and handedness

finding: SNP rs7625916, located in an intergenic region of RP11-91A15.1 on chromosome 3, was linked to a broadly rightward shift in hemispheric differences for minor allele carriers (A, MAF = 0.40), although the effect was not consistent across all differences.
title: Imaging genetics of language network functional connectivity reveals links with language-related abilities, dyslexia and handedness

finding: The lead SNP rs13321297, located in an intronic region near TBC1D5 on chromosome 3, was associated with a broadly rightward shift in hemispheric differences for carriers of the minor allele (A, MAF = 0.31).
title: Imaging genetics of language network functional connectivity reveals links with language-related abilities, dyslexia and handedness

finding: The SNP rs9880772 was linked to a higher risk of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) through genome-wide association studies (GWAS). This finding suggested that individuals with this SNP may have a deregulated immune function, contributing to impaired control of CLL development.
title: EOMES and IL-10 regulate anti-tumor activity of PD-1+ CD4+ T-cells in B-cell Non-Hodgkin lymphoma

finding: The SNP rs6773363 was associated with an increased risk of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) in GWAS. This association indicated that the presence of this SNP might influence immune responses in ways that promote the development of DLBCL.
title: EOMES and IL-10 regulate anti-tumor activity of PD-1+ CD4+ T-cells in B-cell Non-Hodgkin lymphoma

finding: The SNP rs3806624 was found to be associated with a higher risk of Hodgkin’s lymphoma in genome-wide association studies (GWAS). This finding pointed to a potential relationship between this genetic variation and alterations in immune function that could predispose individuals to Hodgkin’s lymphoma.
title: EOMES and IL-10 regulate anti-tumor activity of PD-1+ CD4+ T-cells in B-cell Non-Hodgkin lymphoma

finding: The lead SNP rs62232870 on chromosome 3p25.1 was associated with an increased odds ratio (OR) of 1.36 [1.25 – 1.48] for dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM), showing a statistically significant association (p = 5.3 × 10<sup>−13</sup>) in both discovery and replication cohorts.
title: Genome wide association analysis in dilated cardiomyopathy reveals two new key players in systolic heart failure on chromosome 3p25.1 and 22q11.23

finding: The second SNP rs4684185 at chr3p25 showed a statistical association with DCM (p = 5.0 × 10<sup>−4</sup>) after adjusting for the lead SNP rs62232870, indicating its relevance in the DCM risk framework.
title: Genome wide association analysis in dilated cardiomyopathy reveals two new key players in systolic heart failure on chromosome 3p25.1 and 22q11.23

finding: The SNP rs11708067, positioned in an islet enhancer near the ADCY5 gene, was linked to its transcription start site (TSS). The risk allele was associated with reduced ADCY5 expression and impaired insulin secretion, reflecting its role in type 2 diabetes pathology, with PPAg reported at 0.79.
title: Single cell ATAC-seq in human pancreatic islets and deep learning upscaling of rare cells reveals cell-specific type 2 diabetes regulatory signatures

finding: The SNP rs62625034 was found to have a high correlation with the CCR5-\u039432 deletion, which is a 32 base pair deletion in the CCR5 gene. Previous studies had reported evidence suggesting a recessive deleterious effect of the \u039432 deletion mutation, particularly an increased mortality rate among homozygous individuals, which was supported by findings in both the UKB-WES and gnomAD datasets. The study confirmed that only the unimputed genotypes obtained through rs62625034 should be used to identify the effect of \u039432 in UKB data.
title: Deviations from Hardy Weinberg Equilibrium at CCR5-Δ32 in Large Sequencing Data Sets

finding: This SNP exhibited allelic imbalance in analyses and was associated with reduced T2D risk. The G allele, linked to increased chromatin accessibility, was found to coincide with an E2F2 binding footprint.
title: Functional interrogation of twenty type 2 diabetes-associated genes using isogenic hESC-derived β-like cells

finding: rs36118024, located in NR2C2, potentially disrupted NOP58 regulation on an RNA editing event in FGD5-AS1, contributing to neurodegeneration. Significant associations indicated how this variant could affect editing related processes and the involvement of FGD5-AS1 in neurodegenerative pathways was highlighted.
title: Genetic control of RNA editing in Neurodegenerative disease

finding: The SNP rs1989839 was utilized to quantify allele-specific methylation (ASM) in the context of RASSF1A promotor methylation. In the experimental setup, it served as a stable reference for calculating the methylation ratio by distinguishing between fully methylated DNA from cell line Mel-270 and fully unmethylated DNA from PBMC 2. The precise quantification of this SNP allowed researchers to ascertain the actual diluted methylation fraction, thus validating the mixed ratios of the samples.
title: Quantification of DNA methylation using methylation-sensitive restriction enzymes and multiplex digital PCR

finding: The SNP rs6441224 was found to influence transcriptional activity and was associated with prognostically relevant hypermethylation of RARRES1 in the context of prostate cancer. This connection has implications for understanding the molecular pathways involved in cancer progression and potential therapeutic approaches.
title: Intercellular crosstalk regulating ARRB2/RARRES1 is involved in transition from fibrosis to cancer

finding: Located near the LMOD3/FRMD4B genes, this SNP was particularly linked to Crohn's disease (CD) and showed a significant effect on the binding affinity of FOSL1, FOSL2, and BATF.
title: The AP-1 factors FOSL1 and FOSL2 co-regulate human Th17 responses

finding: The SNP rs884370 was identified as a significant genetic marker associated with the width of the left hemisphere central sulcus, a brain structure critical for manual motor skills and dexterity. Its association traced back to an enhancer element active during fetal brain development, which regulated the expression of adjacent genes ZIC4 and ZIC1, both implicated in neurogenesis. The trait-increasing T allele of rs884370 was associated with increased expression of ZIC4 and ZIC1 in adult brain tissue and was traced to a shared polymorphism in human and archaic human lineages including Neandertals and Denisovans, indicating its evolutionary significance. The age of this allele was estimated to be approximately 54,171 generations, suggesting a long evolutionary history related to human brain structure adaptations.
title: Neuroimaging genomics as a window into the evolution of human sulcal organization

finding: The rs3181080 variant was identified as a significant genetic risk factor associated with severe COVID-19 symptoms and hospitalization. It was found to enhance binding motifs for important transcription factors (IRF and AP1) that promote monocyte and macrophage activation, ultimately increasing expression of the CCR1 gene in multiple tissues, including lungs. The association was statistically significant with GWAS P-value of 1.8e-16.
title: CCR1 regulatory variants linked to pulmonary macrophage recruitment in severe COVID-19

finding: The rs34919616 variant was also recognized as a critical risk factor for severe COVID-19, disrupting a regulatory motif important for BCL6, a known suppressor of inflammatory gene expression in macrophages. This variant was strongly linked to increased CCR1 expression across various tissues, with a GWAS P-value of 1.04e-16, aligning with its role in enhancing macrophage inflammatory responses.
title: CCR1 regulatory variants linked to pulmonary macrophage recruitment in severe COVID-19

finding: The study found that the haplotype including rs2305619 was associated with increased susceptibility to invasive pneumococcal disease (IPD), being more frequent in the patient cohort compared to healthy controls.
title: Regulation of inflammation and protection against invasive pneumococcal infection by the long pentraxin PTX3

finding: Similar to rs2305619, this SNP was part of the haplotype that demonstrated a significant association with increased susceptibility to IPD in patients compared to controls.
title: Regulation of inflammation and protection against invasive pneumococcal infection by the long pentraxin PTX3

finding: The polymorphism rs3816527, resulting in an amino acid substitution at position 48, was linked with lower circulating levels of PTX3 and was a component of haplotypes that conferred susceptibility to pneumococcus infection, with significant differences noted between patients and controls.
title: Regulation of inflammation and protection against invasive pneumococcal infection by the long pentraxin PTX3

finding: The SNP rs355079 showed a genome-wide significant interaction with sex on lung function but indicated an opposite direction of effect in males compared to females, suggesting sex-specific influences on lung function.
title: SNPs associated with HHIP expression have differential effects on lung function in males and females

finding: It was confirmed through GenIE that this SNP had significant effects associated with both deletions and knock-in alleles in the FOXP1 gene, indicating its importance in transcriptional activity.
title: Variant-to-function dissection of rare non-coding GWAS loci with high impact on blood traits

finding: The regulation of the PLCL2 gene was observed, indicating its role in the expression profile of monocytes.
title: Variant-to-function dissection of rare non-coding GWAS loci with high impact on blood traits

finding: This SNP led to opposite effects on the expression of PTPN7 and CCR2 in whole blood, demonstrating a role in lineage restriction.
title: Variant-to-function dissection of rare non-coding GWAS loci with high impact on blood traits

finding: It was associated with differential expression in the CCR2 gene, highlighting its significance in myeloid lineage regulation.
title: Variant-to-function dissection of rare non-coding GWAS loci with high impact on blood traits

finding: Exhibited ATU regulation in the GATA2 gene, demonstrating its impact within hematopoietic lineages.
title: Variant-to-function dissection of rare non-coding GWAS loci with high impact on blood traits

finding: This SNP had significant expression effects in the EEFSEC gene, indicative of its regulatory capability.
title: Variant-to-function dissection of rare non-coding GWAS loci with high impact on blood traits

finding: The rs9839776 SNP was identified as a polymorphism in the lncRNA SOX2OT, which had an association with gastric cancer risk in a case-control study, particularly in Korean populations.
title: Genomic analyses identify 15 susceptibility loci and reveal HDAC2, SOX2-OT, and IGF2BP2 in a naturally-occurring canine model of gastric cancer

finding: Located near TAMM41, rs142823282 was associated with microalbuminuria (OR = 6.75, P = 1.13×10^-11) and acted as a cis-eQTL for the PPARG gene, involving pathways important for adipocyte regulation and potential kidney disease prevention.
title: Genome-wide association study of diabetic kidney disease highlights biology involved in renal basement membrane collagen

finding: The SNP rs13081946 was associated with the role of macrophages in cancer development and therapy, as discussed in the context of a study that highlighted interactions between senescent cells and macrophages. The findings indicated that macrophage recruitment to transformed tissues, influenced by senescent cells, plays a tumor-promoting role, which was significant in understanding the complexities of cancer biology in relation to this SNP.
title: Senescent cells and macrophages cooperate through a multi-kinase signaling network to promote intestinal transformation in Drosophila

finding: The SNP rs2371816 demonstrated an association with higher serum levels of EGFR, which was linked to elevated coronary artery calcium in both MESA and Framingham studies.
title: Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor Inhibition Prevents Caveolin-1-dependent Calcifying Extracellular Vesicle Biogenesis

finding: The SNP rs2279829 in the 3q24 region was associated with multiple functional connectivity traits, indicating its role in the network interactions of the brain.
title: Common variants contribute to intrinsic functional architecture of human brain

finding: Found at the 3p11.1 location, rs7650184 showed significant associations with functional connectivity traits, further linking it to brain network functions.
title: Common variants contribute to intrinsic functional architecture of human brain

finding: It was prioritized as a causal regulatory variant in schizophrenia by scoring higher than GWAS SNPs rs11708578 and rs17194490.
title: WEVar: a novel statistical learning framework for predicting noncoding regulatory variants

finding: Located in the SCN10A intronic region, it modulated cardiac SCN5A expression and was assigned the highest score in its risk locus.
title: WEVar: a novel statistical learning framework for predicting noncoding regulatory variants

finding: The SNP rs137854888 represented a single homozygous intronic pathogenic variant in the gene DNAJC19, discovered in the Dariusleut Hutterite population, which caused abnormal splicing and led to a truncated, non-functional protein. This variant was directly linked to dilated cardiomyopathy with ataxia syndrome (DCMA), a serious autosomal recessive disorder characterized by significant clinical manifestations such as developmental delays and cardiac failure.
title: SS-31 Reverses Mitochondrial Fragmentation in Fibroblasts from Patients with DCMA, a Mitochondrial Cardiomyopathy

finding: The rs35677470 SNP was associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), rheumatoid arthritis (RA), and systemic sclerosis (SS). This indicated its significant role in autoimmunity, with the findings highlighting the importance of Dnase1L3 in degrading extracellular DNA to prevent autoimmune disorders, particularly in conditions characterized by the accumulation of extracellular DNA.
title: Structural features of Dnase1L3 responsible for serum antigen clearance

finding: The SNP rs2352974, located on Chromosome 3, had previously reported associations with general cognitive ability, educational attainment, intelligence, and math ability. In this study, it exhibited significant heterogeneity, with its largest associations appearing with complex cognitive task measures such as VNR, Tower, Matrices, and Trails-B, while its associations with basic cognitive processes were found to be negligible.
title: Genetic “General Intelligence,” Objectively Determined and Measured

finding: This SNP was part of a small group of disease-associated SNPs located in regions of accessibility in embryonic neural progenitors. It was observed to interact with genes involved in determining interneuron fate and was represented by a green arc, indicating its significance in genetic regulation.
title: Single cell chromatin accessibility reveals regulatory elements and developmental trajectories in the embryonic forebrain

finding: rs142351870 was identified as a disease-associated SNP that mapped to presumptive enhancers relevant to embryonic cell types. Its strong association was underlined by a significant p-value, indicating its potential impact on gene expression during neurodevelopment.
title: Single cell chromatin accessibility reveals regulatory elements and developmental trajectories in the embryonic forebrain

finding: This SNP was characterized as an important candidate associated with disease via enhancer interactions in embryonic cells. The original finding connected it with specific embryonic cell type markers, showcasing its potential role in neuronal development.
title: Single cell chromatin accessibility reveals regulatory elements and developmental trajectories in the embryonic forebrain

finding: The SNP rs13081946 was positively associated with macrophage activity in cancer, indicating that allelic variations might influence macrophage roles in tumor progression and therapeutic responses, particularly noted in the context of bladder cancer, where high macrophage infiltration correlated with poor therapeutic responses.
title: Temporal genomic analysis of melanoma rejection identifies regulators of tumor immune evasion

finding: The SNP rs2886870 was associated with the expression of the gene MB21D2. It was predicted to affect NFKB binding affinity with a significant eQTL effect observed, indicated by a beta of -0.14 and a gene level FDR adjusted p-value of 1.60×10^-4.
title: Functional effects of variation in transcription factor binding highlight long-range gene regulation by epromoters

finding: The study highlighted a significant association of the rs13071590 SNP with the morphological variations induced by the pooled CRISPR and imaging techniques. This association was contextualized within pathways relevant to cellular responses, particularly in the realm of cancer cell morphology, thereby underscoring the potential role of this SNP in influencing gene functions as revealed through deep learning methods.
title: A Pooled Cell Painting CRISPR Screening Platform Enables de novo Inference of Gene Function by Self-supervised Deep Learning

finding: The SNP rs11710930 at the SLC12A8 locus was found to overlap a ChIP-seq peak for the HNF4A transcription factor and was associated with increased binding likelihood. This SNP contributed to causal insights regarding lipid levels and T2D risk, implicating its role as an effector gene.
title: Characterization of non-coding variants associated with transcription factor binding through ATAC-seq-defined footprint QTLs in liver

finding: This variant was associated with the TF gene and showed voxel-wise correlations similar to rs1800562. It highlighted significant patterns of association with the mechanisms of iron transport in the brain.
title: Phenotypic and genetic associations of quantitative magnetic susceptibility in UK Biobank brain imaging

finding: The variant rs9867473, associated with the TFRC gene, demonstrated similarities in spatial associations to those of SLC40A1 and highlighted the role of transferrin in brain iron homeostasis.
title: Phenotypic and genetic associations of quantitative magnetic susceptibility in UK Biobank brain imaging

finding: The rs1015164 SNP was found to be significantly associated with smaller HIV reservoir size (usRNA: β = -0.39, p = 0.027) among individuals of European ancestry. This SNP is a long noncoding RNA variant that regulates differential CCR5 expression. The association reached near-statistical significance in the total population as well (usRNA: β = -0.30, p = 0.051), indicating that this finding relates to the observed impact of CCR5 mutations on HIV control.
title: Host variation in type I interferon signaling genes (MX1), CCR5Δ32, and MHC class I alleles in treated HIV+ non-controllers predict viral reservoir size

finding: The SNP rs55961674 was identified as an intronic variant of KPNA1, which exhibited low specific expression in DA neurons. However, the gene CASR, which encodes the calcium sensing receptor, showed the most specific expression in DA neurons and was confirmed to be significantly enriched in this cell type. This finding indicated that variation in CASR could potentially influence PD risk.
title: Single cell spatial transcriptomic and translatomic profiling of dopaminergic neurons in health, ageing and disease

finding: The SNP rs9289231 was located within an intron of the KALRN gene and was associated with early-onset coronary artery disease (CAD). This finding highlighted the role of KALRN in CAD susceptibility, likely through its interaction with inducible nitric oxide synthase, which is crucial in regulating cardiovascular processes.
title: Human library of cardiac promoters and enhancers

finding: The MHU allele OTR-rs1042778(G) present in modern humans was associated with autism spectrum disorder (ASD), aggression in males, as well as positive traits like prosocial fund allocations and high altruistic behaviors.
title: Oxytocin and vasotocin receptor variation sheds light into the evolution of human prosociality

finding: The MHU allele OTR-rs237885(T) was found to be the major allele in modern human populations, indicating a potential link to social behavior.
title: Oxytocin and vasotocin receptor variation sheds light into the evolution of human prosociality

finding: The OTR-rs6770632(C) allele was identified as the most functional among the sites with modern human specific variation, implicated in social cognition and showing high derived allele frequency in modern human populations.
title: Oxytocin and vasotocin receptor variation sheds light into the evolution of human prosociality

finding: The OTR-rs59190448(G) variant, major in modern human populations, was demonstrated to be under positive selection, indicating its importance in social traits.
title: Oxytocin and vasotocin receptor variation sheds light into the evolution of human prosociality

finding: The OTR-rs237888(T) allele, which was positively selected and major in modern humans, exhibited high functionality and significance in social interactions.
title: Oxytocin and vasotocin receptor variation sheds light into the evolution of human prosociality

finding: The Alt risk allele of rs66473811 at the PSMD6 locus affected the MAZ transcription factor binding site. MAZ promotes breast cancer cell proliferation through tumor-specific expression of PPARγ1 and regulation of MYC expression, implicating this SNP in increased breast cancer risk.
title: High throughput PRIME editing screens identify functional DNA variants in the human genome

finding: The SNP rs428239 was associated with lower expression of circSLC4A7 but did not have a similar association with the mRNA expression of SLC4A7. Additionally, this SNP was noted to colocalize with a high blood pressure GWAS locus, indicating its relevance to cardiovascular traits.
title: Genetic Regulation of Circular RNA Expression in Human Aortic Smooth Muscle Cells and Vascular Traits

finding: The SNP rs34460587 was identified within the LZTFL1 locus on chromosome 3p21.31, which harbored numerous SNPs associated with COVID-19 clinical outcomes. It exhibited a highly significant association with hospitalization versus non-hospitalized COVID-19 cases, indicated by a p-value of less than 5 x 10^-8 and a -log p-value greater than 15. Furthermore, this SNP was located within -300 to +100 bp of transcription start sites (TSS) situated in the intergenic region between the CCR1 and XCR1 genes. This finding underscored the potential role of rs34460587 in influencing disease severity and clinical outcome in COVID-19 patients.
title: Profiling Transcription Initiation in Peripheral Leukocytes Reveals Severity-Associated Cis-Regulatory Elements in Critical COVID-19

finding: The SNP rs116726862 in SLC9A9 was associated with increased levels of Aβ40 in the TX fraction and suggested an associated trend with increased AD risk, Thal phase and CAA.
title: Genome-wide association study of brain biochemical phenotypes reveals distinct genetic architecture of Alzheimer’s Disease related proteins

finding: The SNP rs13061362 had been associated with a specific immature subset of polymorphonuclear myeloid-derived suppressor cells (PMN-MDSC) that was correlated to the response to checkpoint inhibitor therapy in patients suffering from metastatic melanoma. This finding highlighted the significance of this SNP in understanding immune responses to cancer therapies.
title: The ratio of adaptive to innate immune cells differs between genders and associates with improved prognosis and response to immunotherapy

finding: The SNP rs674303 (c.1674A>G) was heterozygous in one of four tested samples, which also featured an Alu insertion in the intronic region of the <italic>NEK10</italic> gene (c.26+891_908insAlu). This insertion was linked to molecular consequences relevant to cancer risk.
title: A systematic screen of breast cancer patients’ exomes for retrotransposon insertions reveals disease associated genes

finding: The SNP rs7637813 was associated with a significant genomic region in the study, showing a nominal p-value of 7.2 × 10^-8. This finding was highly accurate and closely replicated the results from the original study, indicating its importance in the context of genome-wide significance.
title: Truly Privacy-Preserving Federated Analytics for Precision Medicine with Multiparty Homomorphic Encryption

finding: SNP rs1015164 was noted in the discussion, being 9 Kbp away from rs7637813, and located in the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) region, which has established ties to HIV-1 disease progression. Although not directly observed in the analyzed data set, its proximity to the primary findings suggests it maintained relevance through linkage disequilibrium.
title: Truly Privacy-Preserving Federated Analytics for Precision Medicine with Multiparty Homomorphic Encryption

finding: The rs12494328 SNP was significant for Normal-tension glaucoma (NTG) (P=1.7e-08) but not for overall POAG (P=7.5e-07). It reached genome-wide significance in the 23andMe replication study, indicating its strong relevance in NTG.
title: A large cross-ancestry meta-analysis of genome-wide association studies identifies 69 novel risk loci for primary open-angle glaucoma and includes a genetic link with Alzheimer’s disease

finding: The SNP rs11922293 was identified as a significant mQTL SNP associated with a specific season-of-conception (SoC)-CpG site. This finding emerged from a large-scale analysis where it was the only SNP to pass a Bonferroni-adjusted significance threshold among 258 unique G1 and G2 SNPs, suggesting a robust link between this genetic variant and DNAm patterns related to season-of-conception. The data indicated that this SNP was not in proximity to any other G1 SNPs, reinforcing the absence of widespread genetic confounding in the context of the studied SoC-associated DNA methylation patterns.
title: Environmentally sensitive hotspots in the methylome of the early human embryo

finding: The SNP rs4642101 was also found to contribute to postoperative atrial fibrillation, highlighting its importance in the genetic factors associated with cardiac rhythm disorders.
title: Muscle specific translational control of Cand2 by mTORC1 regulates adverse cardiac remodeling

finding: The SNP rs13092112 was implicated in restoring anti-leukemic responses in CLL. The findings suggested that this locus is critical for improving therapeutic approaches through immune modulation.
title: Leukemic cell-secreted interleukin-9 suppresses cytotoxic T cell-mediated killing in chronic lymphocytic leukemia

finding: The rs3814057 polymorphism of the PXR gene was associated with significantly increased risk of hepatotoxicity. Both the heterozygous genotype and homozygous mutant-type showed increased risk compared to the homozygous wild-type, with odds ratios of 1.98 and 2.18, respectively.
title: Association of variants within the GST and other genes with anti-tubercular agents related toxicity: a systematic review and meta-analysis

finding: This SNP was located inside the large PTPRG gene and looped over more than 200kb to its promoter, being associated with the QT interval (P = 8 x 10^-7).
title: Detailed Regulatory Interaction Map of the Human Heart Facilitates Gene Discovery for Cardiovascular Disease

finding: This SNP was located within the ITGA9 gene and associated with the PR interval (P = 4.14 x 10^-11), looping to its promoter.
title: Detailed Regulatory Interaction Map of the Human Heart Facilitates Gene Discovery for Cardiovascular Disease

finding: The SNP rs777947557 corresponds to the missense mutation L104<sup>3.32</sup>I in human OR5K1, which is part of a set of 22 amino acids speculated to make up a generalized odorant binding pocket in odorant receptors. Both amino acids have been experimentally identified as odorant interaction partners in various studies. Mutation of L104 to alanine (L104<sup>3.32</sup>A) resulted in an EC<sub>50</sub> value of 525.28 ± 92.28 µM when stimulated with compound 1, indicating its significant role in ligand recognition.
title: Modeling the Orthosteric Binding Site of the G Protein-Coupled Odorant Receptor OR5K1

finding: The SNP rs1032366530 corresponds to the missense mutation L255<sup>6.51</sup>F in human OR5K1. Similar to L104, this position is also part of a proposed generalized odorant binding pocket and has been confirmed as an interaction partner for odorants. Mutating L255 to alanine (L255<sup>6.51</sup>A) yielded an EC<sub>50</sub> of 478.36 ± 185.10 µM with compound 1, further supporting its importance in the activation of OR5K1.
title: Modeling the Orthosteric Binding Site of the G Protein-Coupled Odorant Receptor OR5K1

finding: The SNP rs7613875 correlated with creativity and was located near IP6K2, a gene involved in the physiology related to schizophrenia (SCZ) and ADHD, thus supporting the genetic connection between creativity and mental health conditions.
title: Genetic architecture of creativity and extensive genetic overlap with psychiatric disorders revealed from genome-wide association analyses of 241,736 individuals

finding: Identified as a significant SNP for creativity, rs73078357 was situated within the intron region of the RBM6 gene, which was associated with overall cognitive performance and schizophrenia (SCZ), indicating a shared genetic basis.
title: Genetic architecture of creativity and extensive genetic overlap with psychiatric disorders revealed from genome-wide association analyses of 241,736 individuals

finding: SNP rs9844736 was linked to both RiskyBehavior and SmokingInitiation, with p-values of 3.04 x 10^-7 and 3.58 x 10^-7, respectively. It demonstrated predicted activity across all three neuronal cell types analyzed and was also a cis-eQTL for adjacent genes in striatal regions, suggesting its role in gene regulation associated with addiction.
title: Addiction-associated genetic variants implicate brain cell type- and region-specific cis-regulatory elements in addiction neurobiology

finding: The SNP rs11708067 was tied to a co-localised eQTL-GWAS signal at the ADCY5 locus, where the A allele was associated with a greater risk of type 2 diabetes along with lower ADCY5 expression in islets. Its results were further corroborated by chromatin interaction studies.
title: Inferring causal genes at type 2 diabetes GWAS loci through chromosome interactions in islet cells

finding: The study indicated that the SNP rs13092151 was associated with ATRX alteration in a context where this alteration contributed to tumor growth and immune escape in pleomorphic sarcomas. This finding was significant as it linked specific genetic alterations with the aggressive nature of tumors like leiomyosarcoma.
title: Distinct cellular origins and differentiation process account for distinct oncogenic and clinical behaviors of leiomyosarcomas

finding: In the IAV perturbation experiment, this reQTL had a specific colocalization with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Notably, the eQTL effect of rs11721168 for the gene PXK decreased after perturbation, indicating a dynamic interaction influenced by the perturbation state.
title: Modeling heterogeneity in single-cell perturbation states enhances detection of response eQTLs

finding: The findings related to the SNP rs6782181 were significant in the study performed by Wu et al. (2015), which indicated an association between the MARS polymorphism at this SNP and serum lipid levels. This provided evidence that perturbations related to this SNP could affect downstream traits associated with lipid metabolism.
title: MRLocus: identifying causal genes mediating a trait through Bayesian estimation of allelic heterogeneity

finding: The SNP rs13081778 was linked to distinct metabolic reprogramming associated with different states of epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) activities. This finding underscored the role of metabolism in driving the transition towards aggressive hybrid E/M-W/O states in cancer cells, highlighting the significance of this SNP in the context of cancer metastasis.
title: Decoding the coupled decision-making of the epithelial-mesenchymal transition and metabolic reprogramming in cancer

finding: The SNP rs60464856 was identified as a significant risk factor for prostate cancer (PCa) progression. Carriers of the G allele had a higher risk for PCa with a reported p-value of 1.2E-16 in over 107,000 cases compared to controls. Moreover, eQTL analysis demonstrated that this G allele was associated with increased expression of the gene RUVBL1 in multiple datasets, including GTEx and TCGA. Functional studies using CRISPRi and base editing further confirmed that the G allele led to elevated RUVBL1 expression, which correlated with enhanced PCa cell growth and was linked to poor patient survival outcomes, reinforcing its role in PCa susceptibility.
title: Combined CRISPRi and proteomics screening reveal a cohesin-CTCF-bound allele contributing to increased expression of RUVBL1 and prostate cancer progression

finding: The SNP rs13081950 was associated with the genomic landscape of lobular breast cancer as detailed in the work of McCart Reed et al. (2021). The study illustrated how this particular SNP contributed to the understanding of the metabolic subtypes in breast cancer, impacting biological pathways and potentially influencing clinical outcomes such as prognosis and chemosensitivity.
title: Discovery of multi-state gene cluster switches determining the adaptive mitochondrial and metabolic landscape of breast cancer

finding: The SNP rs13071497 was evaluated for its diagnostic accuracy in predicting capecitabine-related toxicities, highlighting its relevance in the context of anticancer drug response and safety.
title: Expansion of a bacterial operon during cancer treatment ameliorates drug toxicity

finding: The SNP rs13081873 was identified as a significant finding in the context of metabolic changes associated with Toxoplasma gondii infection in host cells. The study highlighted that modifications in the metabolic environment were observed using various methodologies, and these changes were linked to alterations in host cell function, which were further characterized by changes in NAD(P)H ratios, reactive oxygen species production, and glucose metabolism.
title: Metabolic changes to host cells with Toxoplasma gondii infection

finding: The SNP rs9832461 was linked to MYRIP, an insulin secretion regulator, which exhibited low expression in capillary endothelial cells in AD. This locus was examined through both Hi-C loops and enhancer-gene correlation, indicating a potential dysregulation of insulin signaling within the endothelial cells of AD patients.
title: Single-cell multi-region dissection of brain vasculature in Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: The SNP rs13071494 was highlighted in the context of glioblastoma (GBM) development, where high expression of MAGOH and MAGOHB was linked to the splicing profile alterations in GBM cells. It was established that this SNP had a significant association with poor prognosis in glioma patients, which suggests its influence on critical cellular processes such as cell division and splicing, essential for efficient tumor growth.
title: The paralogues MAGOH and MAGOHB are oncogenic factors in high-grade gliomas and safeguard the splicing of cell division and cell cycle genes

finding: The rs145061115 SNP, resulting in a C20S amino acid change, was found to destabilize the CCR5 protein structure and might disrupt function due to potential loss of hydrophobic interactions. This variant was noted to be present in the European population with a minor allele frequency of 0.001%.
title: In silico analysis of single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in human C-C chemokine receptor type five (CCR5) gene

finding: The SNP rs199824195, causing a C178R substitution, was identified as affecting a conserved cysteine critical for disulfide bonding, which is important for CCR5 structure and HIV binding. This change led to potential protein folding issues and was predominantly found in East Asian populations, with a minor allele frequency of 0.003%.
title: In silico analysis of single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in human C-C chemokine receptor type five (CCR5) gene

finding: The mutation at rs201797884, resulting in a W190R/G change, affected local stability of the CCR5 protein. While not directly in contact with ligands, this change could have detrimental effects on neighboring residues' interactions.
title: In silico analysis of single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in human C-C chemokine receptor type five (CCR5) gene

finding: The finding related to the rs616147 SNP showed that the polymorphism in myelin-associated oligodendrocyte basic protein was identified as a risk factor for Parkinson's disease. This association provided evidence for the role of this genetic variant in the susceptibility to Parkinson's, underscoring its potential significance in understanding the disease's etiology.
title: Transcript-specific enrichment enables profiling rare cell states via scRNA-seq

finding: This SNP was identified as a missense cis-pQTL affecting LRIG1 protein levels, showing a causal association with reduced risk of atrial fibrillation and type 2 diabetes, with a notable statistical impact on BMI.
title: Whole genome sequencing analysis of the cardiometabolic proteome

finding: This SNP, when added to the analysis of rs62556120, altered the risk association, demonstrating a causal relationship with height.
title: Whole genome sequencing analysis of the cardiometabolic proteome

finding: The polymorphism rs13064994 located in intron 1 was positively associated with increased MASP-3 serum levels in healthy individuals. Carriers of the rs13064994*T variant showed higher MASP-3 levels compared to C/C homozygotes, but this association disappeared in leprosy patients who exhibited generally lower MASP-3 concentrations.

The exon 12 variant rs1109452 was associated with lower MASP-3 levels in healthy individuals, although similar levels were observed between healthy and diseased carriers. Furthermore, carriers of the minor rs1109452*T variant presented higher MASP-1 levels, irrespective of the disease status, highlighting its regulatory role.

The exon 12 SNP rs850314 was found to be associated with higher MASP-3 levels among healthy controls carrying the minor allele A, compared to G/G homozygotes. There was also a potential link to disease susceptibility as higher MASP-3 levels were noted in resistance haplotypes that included this SNP.
The oxytocin receptor gene polymorphism (rs2254298) was associated with cardiovascular risk factors, illustrating its potential implications in cardiovascular diseases among Brazilian elderly.
title: Study on potential differentially expressed genes in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis by bioinformatics and next generation sequencing data analysis

finding: The SNP rs13071488 was found to be significantly associated with the expression levels of the MPC1 and MPC2 genes, which are crucial in the metabolism of lung adenocarcinoma (LUAD). This association suggested that genetic variability at this locus contributed to the malignant development of LUAD, as indicated by its involvement in key metabolic pathways related to tumor proliferation and invasion.
title: Development and validation of glycolysis-cholesterol synthesis genes in lung adenocarcinoma

finding: The SNP rs13091999 was associated with reactivation of human endogenous retroviruses, which had implications for cancer immunotherapy. Specifically, this SNP was linked to the identification of a dominant tumor-associated antigen that was recognized by CD8+ T cells in a murine model of melanoma, showcasing its relevance in facilitating T-cell responses to tumor antigens.
title: Identification of highly cross-reactive mimotopes for a public T cell response in murine melanoma

finding: The SNP rs12330631, a conserved SNP, showed an improved PIP of 0.96 for BMI compared to 0.25 as per SuSiE, highlighting the effectiveness of PolyFun in pinpointing this variant.
title: Functionally-informed fine-mapping and polygenic localization of complex trait heritability

finding: The SNP rs2270894, also a promoter SNP, had a PIP of 0.96 for platelet count, a dramatic increase over SuSiE's PIP of 0.19, showcasing the advancements made by PolyFun in fine-mapping capabilities.
title: Functionally-informed fine-mapping and polygenic localization of complex trait heritability

finding: This SNP was associated with cortical thickness and spatially related to EOMES, which is crucial for intermediate progenitor cell development in the fetal cortex, supporting its role in brain structure.
title: The genetic architecture of the human cerebral cortex

finding: Identified as a fetal cortex eQTL for RPSA, rs533577's association underscored its potential role in the neurodevelopmental framework involving cortical thickness.
title: The genetic architecture of the human cerebral cortex

finding: The rs115160714 SNP, which involves a polymorphism in the TOPBP1 gene (c.*229C>T), was found to be associated with an increased risk of endometrial cancer. This indicates a potential relevance of TOPBP1 in cancer predisposition, particularly in relation to DNA repair pathways, which might have implications in the context of BRCA1/2 deficiency.
title: The mitotic CIP2A-TOPBP1 axis facilitates mitotic pathway choice between MiDAS and MMEJ

finding: The rs17713054 risk allele of LZTFL1 generated a CCAAT/enhancer binding protein beta motif, which was reported to be related to various cancer types and COVID-19. This SNP, which involved a G>A transition, was shown to regulate the expression of LZTFL1 in lung samples by interacting with the LZTFL1 promoter. In lung samples from COVID-19 patients, a signal of epithelial-mesenchymal transition was observed, indicating an essential role for the innate immune response in lung epithelial cells. The findings highlighted that LZTFL1 was mainly expressed in ciliated cells and was necessary for cilium organization, thereby supporting its role in the gene's downstream regulation under COVID-19 infection.
title: A pan-cancer analysis of the oncogenic role of COVID-19 risk gene Leucine Zipper Transcription Factor-Like Protein 1 (LZTFL1) in human tumors

finding: The rs9310935 variant near IL5RA showed moderate evidence of association with the latent factor ML8 and was significantly associated with multiple blood cell traits, specifically four basophil-related traits. It remained associated with ML8 when accounting for previously identified lead variants.
title: Improved genetic discovery and fine-mapping resolution through multivariate latent factor analysis of high-dimensional traits

finding: The SNP rs10490770 was included in the haplotypes that carry the minor allele and was found to be in perfect linkage disequilibrium with the leading risk polymorphisms in Eurasian populations. Like rs11385942, carriers of rs10490770 also fall into a clade with Neandertal genomes, contributing to the understanding of the genetic risk factor for severe SARS-CoV-2 infection.
title: The major genetic risk factor for severe COVID-19 is inherited from Neandertals

finding: The rs62271373 SNP, located in an intergenic region near LINC01214, was noted for its overlap with active enhancer chromatin states in adipose and skeletal muscle tissues, indicating potential tissue-specific regulatory roles.
title: The Trans-Ancestral Genomic Architecture of Glycaemic Traits

finding: The rs62292793 variant was discovered to disrupt a binding motif for the transcription factor interferon regulatory factor 1 (IRF1), thus affecting the expression of the RTP4 gene. The alternative allele (A) of this eQTL variant resulted in significantly reduced binding affinity of IRF1, subsequently downregulating RTP4 expression, highlighting a mechanism through which genetic variation could modulate antiviral responses.
title: Mapping interindividual dynamics of innate immune response at single-cell resolution

finding: The SNP rs73178598 was identified in a genome-wide association study (GWAS) as being associated with Psoriasis. This SNP is located approximately 240kb upstream of the SATB1 locus, where it influences the transcription of an antisense non-coding RNA called SATB1-AS1. These findings highlighted the potential regulatory role of this SNP in the context of SATB1 expression, which could affect T cell differentiation and function, particularly in Psoriasis.
title: Identification of a novel enhancer essential for Satb1 expression in TH2 cells and activated ILC2s

finding: The SNP rs147997200 was implicated in affecting the binding of three TF motifs in K562 cell lines, thus participating in regulatory mechanisms within the genomic context of ePromoters.
title: RSAT Var-tools: an accessible and flexible framework to predict the impact of regulatory variants on transcription factor binding

finding: This SNP at ADCY5 was associated with a novel BMI signal, validated in HISLA Stage 2, and showed directional consistency and nominal significance in other consortia.
title: Ancestral diversity improves discovery and fine-mapping of genetic loci for anthropometric traits - the Hispanic/Latino Anthropometry Consortium

finding: The SNP rs3819325 was associated with the gene KLHDC8B, also identified as differentially spliced in relation to AUD. This SNP showed a significant correlation with splicing TWAS associations for problematic alcohol use and was found to be in LD with SNPs related to smoking cessation.
title: Genome- and Transcriptome-wide Splicing Associations with Problematic Alcohol Use and Alcohol Use Disorder

finding: The SNP rs7617480 was found to be in LD with the lead sQTL for KLHDC8B (rs3819325) and was associated with smoking cessation. This connection further highlighted the genetic interplay between substance use disorders, specifically linking AUD and smoking-related traits.
title: Genome- and Transcriptome-wide Splicing Associations with Problematic Alcohol Use and Alcohol Use Disorder

finding: The SNP rs10470352 was identified within the SOX2-SE region, through comprehensive analyses via genome-wide association studies (GWAS) and HiChIP. This genetic variation was found to enable the binding of transcription factors TP73 and RUNX3, which facilitated the formation of active chromatin states and resulted in the upregulation of SOX2 expression. This finding highlighted the significance of this SNP in promoting oncogenic processes related to gastric cancer.
title: Super-enhancer-driven ZFP36L1 promotes PD-L1 expression in infiltrative gastric cancer

finding: The SNP rs13071525 was associated with the modulation of dendritic cell biology which was essential for enhancing the efficacy of cancer immunotherapy. Specifically, in the context of the study on adoptive T cell therapy, the presence of this SNP correlated with improved host immune response, facilitating both immediate tumor debulking and long-term tumor control.
title: Enhancing adoptive T cell therapy with synergistic host immune engagement promotes long-term protection against solid tumors

finding: The SNP rs1800734 was found to enhance the expression of the DCLK3 gene through long-range interactions, which was linked to the promotion of colorectal cancer progression. This finding was significant in understanding the genetic factors contributing to cancer development.
title: WAPL maintains dynamic cohesin to preserve lineage specific distal gene regulation

finding: The SNP rs6795970 demonstrated a significant association with hypoalgesic inflammatory bowel disease phenotype, indicating that homozygosity for the SCN10A polymorphism was linked to reduced pain perception in patients suffering from this condition.
title: Structural basis of inhibition of human NaV1.8 by the tarantula venom peptide Protoxin-I

finding: Individuals with the rs53576 G allele exhibited faster decision-making in response to social evaluations under the influence of oxytocin. This suggests increased sensitivity to oxytocin’s effects, which aligns with known associations of this SNP with enhanced empathy and social behavior.
title: Oxytocin modulation of self-other distinction is replicable and influenced by oxytocin receptor (OXTR) genotype

finding: TT homozygotes of rs2268498 demonstrated significant improvements in memory performance, particularly for managing negatively valenced words during recognition tasks under oxytocin treatment, which conforms to its associations with better social perception and lower autism traits.
title: Oxytocin modulation of self-other distinction is replicable and influenced by oxytocin receptor (OXTR) genotype

finding: The SNP rs13092053 was identified as contributing to the immunosuppressive tumor microenvironment in osteosarcoma. This finding was linked to the presence of myeloid-derived suppressor cells (MDSCs) and regulatory T-cells, which were shown to promote tumor progression and create a proangiogenic niche in the context of osteosarcoma.
title: Immunosuppressive tumor microenvironment of osteosarcoma

finding: The SNP rs53576 in the oxytocin receptor gene was identified as being associated with aggression across seven ethnic groups. This finding was significant and highlighted the role of this genetic variant in influencing behavioral traits, particularly in relation to interpersonal dynamics.
title: No change in oxytocin level before a human intergroup competition: study among Polish players before rugby and handball matches

finding: The rs5186 SNP variant in the Angiotensin II Type 1 Receptor was found to predict the incidence of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) and associated hypertension, highlighting its relevance in metabolic conditions.
title: Identification of novel key genes and signaling pathways in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy: evidence from bioinformatics and next generation sequencing data analysis

finding: The AGTR1 rs5182 polymorphism showed associations with diabetes and lipid effects in an elderly Chinese population, highlighting its metabolic relevance.
title: Identification of novel key genes and signaling pathways in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy: evidence from bioinformatics and next generation sequencing data analysis

finding: Located in the CPOX gene, this variant showed significant association with CSF YKL-40 levels, indicating its genetic impact on this biomarker.
title: TMEM106B and CPOX are genetic determinants of cerebrospinal fluid Alzheimer’s disease biomarker levels

finding: The rs6280 polymorphism in the DRD3 gene was found to be associated with alcohol dependence overall and specifically with Lesch type I alcohol dependence in the Korean population, suggesting a genetic influence on vulnerability to alcohol use disorders.
title: Transcriptional analysis of neuronal ensembles of alcohol memories within the nucleus accumbens

finding: The SNP rs28576629 was identified as having the strongest mvGWAS signal with a genome-wide significance (P=3.79×10^-14). It was located on chromosome 3, within the intronic region of the gene PPP2R3A, which encodes a regulatory subunit of protein phosphatase 2. This finding related to the genetic overlap between rhythm impairment and dyslexia, denoted by the phenotypic correlation FgRI-D.
title: The shared genetic architecture and evolution of human language and musical rhythm

finding: rs7617480 was associated with major depression, showing a notable connection with the gene NDUFAF3, which encodes a protein targeted by Metformin, an important drug for type-2 diabetes treatment. The Z-score was -5.0785 with a GWAS P value of 0.00001.
title: Multi-ancestry GWAS of major depression aids locus discovery, fine-mapping, gene prioritisation, and causal inference

finding: The SNP rs13081946 was linked to a positive finding related to the role of macrophages in cancer development and therapy. This connection was particularly relevant in discussions surrounding immune responses and tumor dynamics, indicating that genetic variation at this locus could influence the interaction between immune and cancer cells.
title: The role of noise in the tumour-immune interactions reveals memoryless shifting response

finding: The SNP rs13097644 was shown to have regulatory implications at various differentiation stages, suggesting its role in the onset of diseases.
title: Allele-specific DNA methylation is increased in cancers and its dense mapping in normal plus neoplastic cells increases the yield of disease-associated regulatory SNPs

finding: The SNP rs9880772 was associated with several cancer types, indicating its potential as a functional regulatory element in tumorigenesis.
title: Allele-specific DNA methylation is increased in cancers and its dense mapping in normal plus neoplastic cells increases the yield of disease-associated regulatory SNPs

finding: The SNP rs3811647 in the Transferrin gene was linked to multiple sclerosis, reflecting its potential role in the pathogenesis or progression of the condition.
title: Identification of candidate biomarkers and pathways associated with multiple sclerosis using bioinformatics and next generation sequencing data analysis

finding: The SNP rs1049296 in the Transferrin gene was identified as associated with multiple sclerosis, suggesting its relevance in the genetic landscape of the disease.
title: Identification of candidate biomarkers and pathways associated with multiple sclerosis using bioinformatics and next generation sequencing data analysis

finding: The rs17279437 (Thr199Met) variant was associated with widespread reductions in sulcal width, suggesting its role in regulating proline and glycine levels in the brain and kidneys.
title: Genetic map of regional sulcal morphology in the human brain

finding: The rs1354034 variant, located within the ARHGEF3 gene, was associated with three co-expression modules in platelets: IC68, X6.WIERENGA_STAT5A_TARGETS_DN, and Cluster_12953. The T allele was found to increase the expression of the ARHGEF3 gene in cis, and both cis and trans-eQTLs colocalised with GWAS hits for mean platelet volume, platelet count, and plateletcrit.
title: Co-expression analysis reveals interpretable gene modules controlled by trans-acting genetic variants

finding: Another SNP, rs115981379 (C>T), was identified within the CTNNB1 gene. eQTL analysis showed differences in CTNNB1 expression levels among samples, with 428 C/C and 37 C/T type esophagus samples, as well as 343 C/C and 25 C/T type transverse colon samples reported, demonstrating the effect of this SNP on gene expression.
title: Wnt signaling dosage controlled by a Ctnnb1 enhancer balances homeostasis and tumorigenesis of intestinal epithelia

finding: The Ala986Ser SNP (rs1801725) was strongly positively associated with serum calcium concentrations, specifically with a p-value of 1.6E-70 and a beta value of 0.07255. This finding indicated that the presence of the Ser986 allele was associated with the highest serum calcium concentrations, contributing to a 6.3% variation in serum calcium levels in the study cohort.
title: Calcium Sensing Receptor Common Variants Influence the Effects of Serum Calcium on Coronary Artery Disease Risks

finding: The Arg990Gly SNP (rs1042636) exhibited a negative association with serum calcium, indicated by a p-value of 5.75E-15 and a beta value of -0.0442. Carriers of the Gly990 allele had a reduced risk of coronary artery disease, which remained significant within specific serum calcium concentration ranges and contributed to 5.4% variation in serum calcium levels in the population.
title: Calcium Sensing Receptor Common Variants Influence the Effects of Serum Calcium on Coronary Artery Disease Risks

finding: The variant rs7615045 was specifically associated with body mass, glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c), and type 2 diabetes, demonstrating significant associations across a large cohort that included 16,278,030 individuals of various ancestries.
title: An adipocyte-specific lncRAP2 – Igf2bp2 complex enhances adipogenesis and energy expenditure by stabilizing target mRNAs

finding: The SNP rs6438208 was identified as a genome-wide significant locus associated with smoking initiation in a larger sample compared to previous single-trait GWAS. It was linked to the gene ZBTB20, previously associated with psychiatric traits.
title: Multi-trait genome-wide association analyses leveraging alcohol use disorder findings identify novel loci for smoking behaviors in the Million Veteran Program

finding: Similar to rs1506537, variant rs56992000 was predicted to increase GATA4-DNA binding. Experimental validation confirmed high binding affinity with negligible binding to the reference allele. The alternate allele corresponded with elevated TOP2B expression in cardiac ventricular tissue.
title: Cardiovascular Disease-Associated Non-Coding Variants Disrupt GATA4-DNA Binding and Regulatory Functions

finding: EGPA-associated rs9290877 lies within LPP and correlated with susceptibility to asthma and allergy, establishing a genetic connection to immune processes.
title: Genetically distinct clinical subsets, and associations with asthma and eosinophil abundance, within Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis

finding: The variant rs167924 located at the 3' end of the CD47 gene was associated with platelet levels, with a beta value of -0.018 and a highly significant p-value of 7.40e-23, indicating its relevance in the regulation of platelet counts.
title: SIRPα controls CD47-dependent platelet clearance in mice and humans

finding: As part of the analysis, rs62250713 was found to be one of several SNPs associated with drinking behavior, indicating its relevance in the study's context.
title: Meta-analysis of problematic alcohol use in 435,563 individuals identifies 29 risk variants and yields insights into biology, pleiotropy and causality

finding: The SNP rs9867864 was positively found to influence the expression of the CHL1 gene through altering chromatin accessibility in progenitors, as shown by significant allele-specific chromatin accessibility (ASCA), with a false discovery rate (FDR) of 9.5 × 10⁻²². However, it did not show similar associations in neurons.
title: Inferring cell-type-specific causal gene regulatory networks during human neurogenesis

finding: This SNP was associated with cocaine use as determined by the L-BRAT test, yielding a P-value of 2.00 × 10^-8, indicating genome-wide significance.
title: Retrospective Association Analysis of Longitudinal Binary Traits Identifies Important Loci and Pathways in Cocaine Use

finding: This SNP was associated with lipid measures indicating potential metabolic implications.
title: Long-range regulatory effects of Neandertal DNA in modern humans

finding: In the RPSA gene, two DASE sites, including rs2269350, showed distinct expression changes post-viral infection, with the reference allele expression declining and the alternative allele increasing.
title: Differential haplotype expression in class I MHC genes during SARS-CoV-2 infection of human lung cell lines

finding: Associated with the ZNF502 gene, this SNP showed significant downregulation in Pitta individuals and was linked to enhanced anti-viral responses compared to Kapha.
title: Genetic differences between extreme and composite constitution types from whole exome sequences reveal actionable variations

finding: The SNP rs13081766 was associated with immune responses, specifically within the context of the BTLA/HVEM axis. This axis was linked to NK cell immunosuppression and a poor clinical outcome in chronic lymphocytic leukemia, demonstrating its relevance in pathologies that might share similarities with the immune dysregulation seen in biliary atresia.
title: Human endogenous retrovirus activation contributes to biliary atresia pathogenesis through re-education of resident macrophages

finding: The SNP rs13092235 was associated with the role of the Ubiquitin Proteasome System in maintaining genome stability and preventing DNA damage. This finding was significant in the context of neurodegenerative diseases such as dementia with Lewy body (DLB), where DNA damage and DDR dysfunction were implicated. The study highlighted how alterations in this pathway could result in increased DSBs in neuronal populations, related to the pathology of alpha-synuclein, suggesting potential avenues for understanding genetic predispositions to synucleinopathies.
title: Post-mortem evidence for a reciprocal relationship between genomic DNA damage and alpha-synuclein pathology in dementia with Lewy bodies

finding: The rs5743836 TLR9 C allele was associated with higher levels of TLR9, IFNα, and SLFN12L expression in the stomachs of individuals infected with Helicobacter. The presence of this minor allele correlated with an increased incidence of gastric intestinal metaplasia (GIM) and gastric cancer (GAC) in Asian cohorts, suggesting a predisposition to neoplastic complications from chronic Helicobacter infection.
title: Toll Like Receptor 9 Pathway Mediates Schlafen+-MDSC Polarization During Helicobacter-Induced Gastric Metaplasias

finding: Associated with locus 3q21.3, this SNP was uniquely linked with protection against retinal disease endophenotypes, indicating a potential inverse relationship with the pathology of MacTel.
title: Genetic Disruption of Serine Biosynthesis is a Key Driver of Macular Telangiectasia Type 2 Etiology and Progression

finding: This SNP at locus 3p24.1 was identified as a significant independent contributor to MacTel and is located near genes with functions that could impact retinal physiology.
title: Genetic Disruption of Serine Biosynthesis is a Key Driver of Macular Telangiectasia Type 2 Etiology and Progression

finding: The study demonstrated that the deletion allele centered on rs6801957 significantly rescued the loss of function observed at the reference allele-bearing element, suggesting that the rs6801957 reference allele, but not the alternate allele, was likely bound by a transcription factor that represses enhancer activity.
title: Functional characterization of QT interval associated SCN5A enhancer variants identify combined additive effects

finding: It was shown that enhancer activity from the deletion allele construct was reduced compared to the reference and alternate allele constructs, indicating that a critical transcription factor binding site was lost in the deletion allele. The transcription factor GATA2 was suggested to bind the reference allele, driving increased enhancer activity.
title: Functional characterization of QT interval associated SCN5A enhancer variants identify combined additive effects

finding: The enhancer activity of the deletion allele was found to be reduced due to the loss of the SP1 binding site, which was confirmed through oligo pulldown assays indicating that SP1 likely binds to the reference allele, contributing to higher enhancer activity compared to the alternate allele.
title: Functional characterization of QT interval associated SCN5A enhancer variants identify combined additive effects

finding: The deletion allele was observed to partially rescue the loss of function at the alternate allele, suggesting that the alternate allele was bound by a repressive transcription factor, while the reference allele exhibited the highest enhancer activity potentially driven by ERF or ELK1.
title: Functional characterization of QT interval associated SCN5A enhancer variants identify combined additive effects

finding: The SNP rs7642482, located on chromosome 3p12.3 near the ROBO2 gene, was associated with expressive vocabulary in infants aged 15-18 months but showed diminished association in toddlers aged 24-30 months, indicating age-specific genetic mechanisms impacting vocabulary development.
title: Genome-wide analyses of vocabulary size in infancy and toddlerhood: associations with Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder and cognition-related traits

finding: The SNP rs9854781 passed the unadjusted genome-wide significance threshold (P<5×10<sup>-8</sup>) for early-phase expressive vocabulary measures in children aged 15-18 months, consistent with previous findings related to rs764282 that displayed a linkage disequilibrium (LD-r<sup>2</sup>) of 0.78.
title: Genome-wide analyses of vocabulary size in infancy and toddlerhood: associations with Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder and cognition-related traits

finding: Identified as a lead modQTL for module 47, this SNP showed an association with SRS1 status and mortality. It was previously linked to inflammatory bowel disease and demonstrated strong colocalization with GWAS signals, suggesting its potential impact on transcriptomic outcomes in sepsis.
title: eQTLs identify regulatory networks and drivers of variation in the individual response to sepsis

finding: The SNP rs2254298 in the oxytocin receptor gene was previously linked to increased symptoms of depression and anxiety among adolescent girls, especially in the context of familial risk for psychopathology. This finding suggested that the interaction between genetic predisposition and environmental factors significantly influenced mental health outcomes.
title: Genetic variation in the social environment affects behavioral phenotypes of oxytocin receptor mutants in zebrafish

finding: The SNP rs2272522 was identified as significantly associated with schizophrenia in a study conducted in Qatar. This finding highlighted the role of the close homologue of L1 gene polymorphism in the etiology of schizophrenia, linking it to the functional implications of L1CAMs that were discussed in the context of their involvement in neurological conditions.
title: A role for the Erk MAPK pathway in modulating SAX-7/L1CAM-dependent locomotion in Caenorhabditis elegans

finding: The rs2855558 variant, located near the <italic>RHO</italic> gene, demonstrated a significant association with myopia genetic risk. Analyses revealed that its allele frequency was positively correlated with sunshine duration in European ancestry populations, suggesting selection favored the derived allele in response to environmental light conditions over approximately the last 20,000 years.
title: Detection of adaptation to light environment in myopia-associated loci Diversity of the myopia genetic background
